properties.description: After the fall of Bianjing, Northern Song migrants brought Mandarin speech to Hangzhou. There, it blended with Wu dialects, forming a unique “Hangzhou Mandarin layer” that preserves traces of northern influence.
During the Ming and Qing dynasties, canal officials stationed in Jiaxing formed Mandarin-speaking communities, surrounded by the local Wu dialect, creating a unique linguistic enclave.

Through the Grand Canal, Suzhou adopted a Mandarin-based reading system for formal texts, while preserving local Wu dialect in daily speech—making it one of China’s most prominent examples of a dual-track language system.
